dt: {bc}deficient supply of blood to a body part (such as the heart or brain) that is due to obstruction of the inflow of arterial blood

et: New Latin {it}ischaemia{/it}, from {it}ischaemus{/it} styptic, from Greek {it}ischaimos{/it}, from {it}ischein{/it} to restrain (akin to Greek {it}echein{/it} to hold) + {it}haima{/it} blood {ma}{mat|scheme:1|}{/ma}
shortdef: deficient supply of blood to a body part (such as the heart or brain) that is due to obstruction of the inflow of arterial blood

dt: {bc}{d_link|stroke|stroke:2} caused by the narrowing or blockage of a blood vessel supplying the brain

Ischemic stroke is the most common type of stroke. Obstruction of a blood vessel supplying the brain results either from a clot that has traveled in the blood from another part of the body (an {d_link|embolism|embolism}) or from a clot that has formed in place (a {d_link|thrombus|thrombus}).

shortdef: stroke caused by the narrowing or blockage of a blood vessel supplying the brain

dt: {bc}a brief episode of cerebral ischemia that is usually characterized by temporary blurring of vision, slurring of speech, numbness, paralysis, or syncope and is often predictive of a serious stroke

shortdef: a brief episode of cerebral ischemia that is usually characterized by temporary blurring of vision, slurring of speech, numbness, paralysis, or syncope and is often predictive of a serious stroke —abbreviation TIA—called also ministroke
